span.span:
S. M. Troshin, N. E. Tyurin
Institute for High Energy Physics,
Protvino, 142284 Russia

div.p: We consider geometrical properties of the polarized and unpolarized structure functions and provide definition for the bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependent structure functions. It is shown that unitarity does not allow factorized form of the structure functions over the xğ‘¥italic-xx and bğ‘italic-bb variables. We conclude that the spin of constituent quark has a significant orbital angular momentum component.

The behavior and dependence of the structure functions on the Bjorken xğ‘¥italic-xx is among the most actively discussed subjects in the unpolarized and polarized deep-inelastic scattering. The particular role here belongs to the small xğ‘¥italic-xx region where asymptotical properties of the strong interactions can be studied. The characteristic point of low-xğ‘¥italic-xx region is an essential nonperturbative nature of the underlying dynamics in the whole region of Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}[1, 2]. Despite the results of perturbative QCD calculations are in a good agreement with the latest HERA data, the conceptual feasibility of the perturbative QCD methods in this region has not been justified.

Of course, the shortcomings of various model approaches to the study of this nonperturbative region are also evident. However, one can hope to gain from these models an information which cannot be obtained from the perturbative methods (cf. [1]). Among the possible extensions there could be considerations of the geometrical features of the structure functions, i.e. dependence of the structure functions on the transverse coordinates or in other words on impact parameter. This dependence would allow one to gain an information on the spatial distribution of the partons inside the parent hadron and the spin properties of the nonperturbative intrinsic hadron structure. The geometrical properties of structure functions should play an important role under analysis of the leptonâ€“nuclei deepâ€“inelastic scattering and in the hard production in the heavyâ€“ion collisions.

section.h2: 1 Definition and interpretation of bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependent structure functions

div.p: In this note we study the bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependence of the structure functions along the line used in [4], i.e. we suppose that the deepâ€“inelastic scattering is determined by the aligned-jet mechanism [1]. There are serious arguments in favor of its leading role and dominance over the other mechanism known as a color-transparency. The aligned-jet mechanism is essentially nonperturbative one and allows to relate structure functions with the discontinuities of the amplitudes of quarkâ€“hadron elastic scattering. These relations have the following form [5, 6]

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ATOM:Im OPEN:[ italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:] VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ATOM:Im OPEN:[ italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:] VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:2 ARG:end ATOM:Im italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) VERTBAR:| POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: The functions Fisubscriptğ¹ğ‘–italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endF_{i} are helicity amplitudes for the elastic quark-hadron scattering in the standard notations for the nucleonâ€“nucleon scattering. We consider high energy limit or the region of small xğ‘¥italic-xx.

The structure functions obtained according to the above formulas should be multiplied by the factor âˆ¼1/Q2similar-toabsent1superscriptğ‘„2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1/Q^{2} â€“ probability that such alignedâ€“jet configuration occurs [1].

The amplitudes Fiâ¢(s,t)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)F_{i}(s,t) are the corresponding Fourier-Bessel transforms of the functions Fiâ¢(s,b)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)F_{i}(s,b).

The relations Eqs. (1) will be used as a starting point under definition of the structure functions which depend on impact parameter. According to these relations it is natural to give the following operational definition:

div.p: and qâ¢(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q(x), Î”â¢qâ¢(x)Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\Delta q(x) and Î´â¢qâ¢(x)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)\delta q(x) are the integrals over bğ‘italic-bb of the corresponding bğ‘italic-bb-dependent distributions, i.e.

div.p: and

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x ARG:end INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-b italic-d italic-b italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The functions qâ¢(x,b)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)q(x,b), Î”â¢qâ¢(x,b)Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta q(x,b) and Î´â¢qâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta q(x,b) depend also on the variable Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2} and have simple interpretations, e.g. the function qâ¢(x,b,Q2)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘superscriptğ‘„2italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b PUNCT:, italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)q(x,b,Q^{2}) represent probability to find quark qğ‘italic-qq in the hadron with a fraction of its longitudinal momenta xğ‘¥italic-xx at the transverse distance

semantics.annotation: italic-b ADDOP:plus-or-minus Delta italic-b PUNCT:, Delta italic-b RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-Q

div.p: from the hadron geometrical center. Interpretation of the spin distributions directly follows from their definitions: they are the differences of the probabilities to find quarks in the two spin states with longitudinal or transverse directions of the quark and hadron spins.

It should be noted that the unitarity plays crucial role in the direct probabilistic interpretation of the function qâ¢(x,b)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)q(x,b). Indeed due to unitarity

semantics.annotation: NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1 PERIOD:.

div.p: The integral qâ¢(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥italic-q OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)q(x) is a quark number density which is not limited by unity and can have arbitrary nonnegative value. Thus, the given definition of the bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependent structure functions is self-consistent. Of course, spin distributions Î”â¢qâ¢(x,b)Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta q(x,b) and Î´â¢qâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta q(x,b) are not positively defined.

section.h2: 2 Unitarity and structure function geometrical profiles

div.p: The unitarity can be fulfilled through the Uğ‘ˆitalic-UUâ€“matrix representation for the helicity amplitudes of elastic quarkâ€“hadron scattering. In the impact parameter representation the expressions for the helicity amplitudes are the following [4]

semantics.annotation: italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-i italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-i italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

div.p: Unitarity requires ImU1,3â¢(x,b)â‰¥0subscriptğ‘ˆ13ğ‘¥ğ‘0italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:greater-than-or-equals NUMBER:0U_{1,3}(x,b)\geq 0. The Uğ‘ˆitalic-UUâ€“matrix form of unitary representation contrary to the eikonal one does not generate itself essential singularity in the complex xğ‘¥italic-xx plane at xâ†’0â†’ğ‘¥0italic-x ARROW:to NUMBER:0x\to 0 and implementation of unitarity can be performed easily. Therefore we use this representation and not the method of the eikonalization. The model which provides explicit form of helicity functions Uiâ¢(x,b)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)U_{i}(x,b) has been described elsewhere [4]. A hadron consists of the constituent quarks aligned in the longitudinal direction and embedded into the nonperturbative vacuum (condensate). The constituent quark appears as a quasiparticle, i.e. as current valence quark surrounded by the cloud of quark-antiquark pairs of different flavors. The strong interaction radius of the constituent quark Qğ‘„italic-QQ is determined by its Compton wavelength.
Spin of constituent quark, e.g. Uğ‘ˆitalic-UU-quark in this approach is given by the sum:

semantics.annotation: italic-J POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 RELOP:equals italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 ADDOP:plus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In the model an exact compensation between the total spin of the quark-antiquark cloud and its angular orbital momenta occurs, i.e.

semantics.annotation: italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: In this approach based on effective Lagrangian the gluon degrees of freedom are overintegrated.

On the grounds of the experimental data for polarized DIS we arrive to conclusion that the significant part of the spin of constituent quark is due to the orbital angular momentum of the current quarks inside the constituent one [3].

The explicit expressions for the helicity functions Uiâ¢(x,b)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)U_{i}(x,b) at small xğ‘¥italic-xx can be obtained from the corresponding functions Uiâ¢(s,b)subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)U_{i}(s,b) given in [4] by the substitute sâ‰ƒQ2/xsimilar-to-or-equalsğ‘ superscriptğ‘„2ğ‘¥italic-s RELOP:similar-to-or-equals italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-xs\simeq Q^{2}/x and at small values of xğ‘¥italic-xx they get the form:

semantics.annotation: italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) OPEN:[ NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-square-root ARG:start italic-x ARG:end MULOP:divide italic-Q CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-x ARG:end ARG:start italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 OPEN:( italic-alpha ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 CLOSE:) italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-b MULOP:divide italic-xi CLOSE:] italic-U POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: ağ‘italic-aa, Î±ğ›¼italic-alpha\alpha, Î²ğ›½italic-beta\beta, gfsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘“italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{f} and Î¾ğœ‰italic-xi\xi are the model parameters, some of them in this particular case of quark-hadron scattering depend on the virtuality Q2superscriptğ‘„2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}.The meaning of these parameters (cf. [4]) is not crucial here; note only that mQsubscriptğ‘šğ‘„italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{Q} is the average mass of constituent quarks in the quark-hadron system of n+1ğ‘›1italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1n+1 quarks and Mğ‘€italic-MM is their total mass, i.e. M=âˆ‘i=1n+1miğ‘€superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘šğ‘–italic-M RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-n ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM=\sum_{i=1}^{n+1}m_{i}. We consider here for simplicity a pure imaginary amplitude. Using definition of the bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependent structure functions given in Sec. 1 and Eqs. (6) we obtain at small xğ‘¥italic-xx:

div.p: where Î²-â¢(Q2)=Î²3â¢(Q2)-Î²1â¢(Q2)subscriptğ›½superscriptğ‘„2subscriptğ›½3superscriptğ‘„2subscriptğ›½1superscriptğ‘„2italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-beta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\beta_{-}(Q^{2})=\beta_{3}(Q^{2})-\beta_{1}(Q^{2}). From the above expressions it follows that qâ¢(x,b)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)q(x,b) has a central bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependence, while Î”â¢qâ¢(x,b)Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta q(x,b) and Î´â¢qâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta q(x,b) have peripheral profiles. Their qualitative dependence on the impact parameter bğ‘italic-bb is depicted in Fig. 1. The peripheral dependence on impact parameter according to the relation Eq. (8) is the manifestation of a significant presence of the angular orbital momenta in the spin balance of a nucleon.

figcaption.span: Low-xğ‘¥italic-xx dependence on bğ‘italic-bb of the structure functions qâ¢(x,b)ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)q(x,b) and Î”â¢qâ¢(x,b)normal-Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta q(x,b)

div.p: From Eqs.(11â€“13) it follows that factorization of xğ‘¥italic-xx and bğ‘italic-bb dependencies is not allowed by unitarity. However, this result is valid for the small xğ‘¥italic-xx region only and approximate factorization is possible in the region of not too small xğ‘¥italic-xx where account of unitarity reduces to the factorization breaking corrections.

The following relation between the structure functions Î”â¢qâ¢(x,b)Î”ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta q(x,b) and Î´â¢qâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta q(x,b) can also be inferred from the above formulas

semantics.annotation: italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-c OPEN:( italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-square-root ARG:start italic-x ARG:end ARG:end ARG:start italic-Q ARG:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-gamma italic-b CLOSE:) Delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Thus, the function Î´â¢qâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-q OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta q(x,b) which describes transverse spin distribution is suppressed by the factors xğ‘¥italic-square-root ARG:start italic-x ARG:end\sqrt{x} and expâ¡(-Î³â¢b)ğ›¾ğ‘OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-gamma italic-b CLOSE:)\exp(-\gamma b), i.e. it has a more central profile. This suppression also reduces double-spin transverse asymmetries in the central region in the Drell-Yan production compared to the corresponding longitudinal asymmetries.

The strange quark structure functions have also a more central bğ‘italic-bbâ€“dependence than in the case of uğ‘¢italic-uu and dğ‘‘italic-dd quarks. The radius of the corresponding quark matter distribution is

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1 ARG:end ARG:start italic-M ARG:end OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-x

div.p: and the ratio of the strange quark distributions to the light quark distributions radii is given by the corresponding constituent quark masses, i.e. for the nucleon this ratio would be

semantics.annotation: italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) MULOP:divide italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:similar-to-or-equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start Delta italic-m ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:4 italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where Î”â¢m=mS-mQÎ”ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘šğ‘†subscriptğ‘šğ‘„Delta italic-m RELOP:equals italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta m=m_{S}-m_{Q}.

Time reversal invariance of strong interactions allows one to write down relations similar to Eqs.(1) for the fragmentation functions also and obtain expressions for the fragmentation functions Dqhâ¢(z,b)superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘§ğ‘italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)D_{q}^{h}(z,b), Î”â¢Dqhâ¢(z,b)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘§ğ‘Delta italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta D_{q}^{h}(z,b), Î´â¢Dqhâ¢(z,b)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘§ğ‘italic-delta italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta D_{q}^{h}(z,b) which have just the same dependence on the impact parameter bğ‘italic-bb as the corresponding structure functions. The fragmentation function Dqhâ¢(z,b,Q2)superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘§ğ‘superscriptğ‘„2italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z PUNCT:, italic-b PUNCT:, italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)D_{q}^{h}(z,b,Q^{2}) is the probability for fragmentation of quark qğ‘italic-qq at transverse distance bÂ±Î”â¢bplus-or-minusğ‘Î”ğ‘italic-b ADDOP:plus-or-minus Delta italic-bb~{}\pm~{}\Delta~{}b (Î”â¢bâˆ¼1/Qsimilar-toÎ”ğ‘1ğ‘„Delta italic-b RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-Q\Delta b\sim 1/Q) into a hadron hâ„italic-hh which carry the fraction zğ‘§italic-zz of the quark momentum. In this case bğ‘italic-bb is a transverse distance between quark qğ‘italic-qq and the center of the hadron hâ„italic-hh. It is positively defined and due to unitarity obey to the inequality

semantics.annotation: NUMBER:0 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-z PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:) RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1

div.p: The physical interpretations of spinâ€“dependent fragmentation functions Î”â¢Dqhâ¢(x,b)Î”superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘¥ğ‘Delta italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\Delta D_{q}^{h}(x,b) and Î´â¢Dqhâ¢(x,b)ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘â„ğ‘¥ğ‘italic-delta italic-D POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-b CLOSE:)\delta D_{q}^{h}(x,b) is similar to that of corresponding spin structure function. Peripherality of the spin fragmentation functions can also be considered as a manifestation of the important role of angular orbital momenta.

It is interesting to note that the spin structure functions have a peripheral dependence on the impact parameter contrary to central profile of the unpolarized structure function. In the considered model where the hadron has aligned structure the peripherality of the spin structure functions implies that the main contribution to the spin of constituent quark is due to the orbital angular momentum. This orbital angular momentum has a nonperturbative origin and does not result from the perturbative QCD evolution. This conclusion provides clue for the possible solution of the problem of the nucleon spin structure. It is interesting to find out possible experimental signatures of the peripheral geometrical profiles of the spin structure functions and the significant role of the orbital angular momentum. One of such indications could be an observation of the different spatial distributions of charge and magnetization at Jefferson Lab [7]. It would also be important to have a precise data for the strange formfactor. It could also be done analyzing both the spin structure and angular distribution in exclusive electroproduction and it worth considering in a separate study.

This work was supported in part by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research under Grant No. 99-02-17995. One of the authors (S.T.) is grateful to Alan Krisch for the warm hospitality at the Spin Physics Center of the University of Michigan where this work was finished.

S. M. Troshin and N. E. Tyurin, Phys. Rev. D 52, 3862 (1995).
S. M. Troshin and N. E. Tyurin, Phys. Rev. D 57, 5447 (1998).
R. L. Jaffe and X. Ji, Phys. Rev. Lett. 67, 552 (1991).
